title: Assumption
what: Assumption is something that is accepted as true without proof. It’s an idea or belief that supports an argument, even if it is not stated directly.
tutorial: If someone says, 'She must be rich because she drives a nice car,' the assumption is that rich people drive nice cars.
steps:
1. Read the argument or statement carefully.
  2. Ask: What must be true for this argument to work?
  3. Find the hidden idea that supports the conclusion.

sections.title: Types of Assumptions
sections.what: Types of assumptions include factual assumptions, belief-based assumptions, and value assumptions. These are ideas taken as true in arguments.
sections.tutorial:
Example:
Factual: It will rain because the sky is dark.
Belief: People are good by nature.
Value: Education is more important than sports.
sections.steps:
1. Identify the argument or idea.
  2. Look at the reason behind the statement.
  3. Classify what type of assumption it is: fact, belief, or value.

sections.title: Factual Assumptions
sections.what: Factual assumptions are based on what the speaker believes is a true event or fact, even without proof.
sections.tutorial: Example: She’s late, so the traffic must be bad. (Assumes bad traffic is the reason)
sections.steps:
1. Find the conclusion.
  2. Ask what fact is assumed to be true for the conclusion to work.
  3. Check if that fact is mentioned or not.

sections.title: Value Assumptions
sections.what: Value assumptions are based on what people believe is important, right, or wrong.
sections.tutorial: Example: Everyone should go to college. (Assumes that education is more valuable than work experience)
sections.steps:
1. Read the opinion or claim.
  2. Ask what value supports this claim.
  3. Find the hidden value that makes the argument strong.

sections.title: Belief-Based Assumptions
sections.what: Belief-based assumptions come from a person’s general view of the world, society, or life.
sections.tutorial: Example: People will always help others in need. (Assumes belief that people are kind)
sections.steps:
1. Identify the generalization or claim.
  2. Ask what belief is needed for the claim to work.
  3. Check if that belief is reasonable or not.

sections.title: Finding Assumptions in Arguments
sections.what: Finding assumptions means discovering the hidden ideas that make an argument possible.
sections.tutorial: Example: He’ll do great in college because he was top in high school. (Assumes top high school students always do great in college)
sections.steps:
1. Find the conclusion and reason.
  2. Ask: What must be true for this reason to support the conclusion?
  3. Check if this idea is stated. If not, it’s the assumption.

sections.title: Assumption vs Inference
sections.what: Assumption is what the author or speaker takes for granted. Inference is what the reader concludes based on the given information.
sections.tutorial:
Assumption: The speaker believes something to be true (even if unstated).
Inference: The reader guesses something from the clues.
sections.steps:
1. Identify the main statement or argument.
  2. Ask: Is this a hidden belief by the author (assumption) or your own conclusion (inference)?
  3. Practice using examples to know the difference.

sections.title: Common Assumption-Based Mistakes
sections.what: Common mistakes include assuming too much, ignoring other possible explanations, and relying on stereotypes.
sections.tutorial: Example: He’s wearing glasses, so he must be smart. (This is a stereotype and a weak assumption.)
sections.steps:
1. Check if your assumption is based on enough facts.
  2. Avoid making conclusions based on looks, race, or background.
  3. Always ask: Is this the only explanation?
